contextId.information: Here Yahweh speaks of not punishing the Israelites as his anger not coming upon them. The phrase "come upon" refers to his anger being applied to them. AT: "so that in my anger I do not punish the people of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: so that my anger does not come upon the people of Israel

contextId.information: Here the author speaks of "descending" as if it were "coming." AT: "The clans descending from" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The clans coming from

contextId.information: Here the author speaks of "descending" as if it were "coming." AT: "descend from Gershon" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: come from Gershon

contextId.information: If a person touched a dead body they were considered unclean. A person who is not acceptable for God's purposes is spoken of as if the person were physically unclean. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: whoever is unclean through touching a dead body

contextId.information: Here Yahweh speaks about claiming the Israelites as his own by saying that he is giving them "his name."  AT: "they must let the people of Israel know that they are mine" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: they must give my name

contextId.information: Yahweh appointing the Levites to help Aaron and his sons is spoken of as if they were a gift that Yahweh were giving to Aaron and his sons. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I have given the Levites as a gift to Aaron and his sons

contextId.information: A person who God considers spiritually unacceptable or defiled is spoken of as if the person were physically unclean. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: unclean

contextId.information: A person who God considers spiritually acceptable is spoken of as if the person were physically clean. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: any person who is clean

contextId.information: Here the phrase "cut off" means to be disowned and sent away. AT: "that person must be sent away" or "you must send that person away" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: that person must be cut off

contextId.information: Here the concept of the man having to bear the consequences of his sin is spoken of as if his sin were a heavy object object that he had to carry. AT: "That man must bear the punishment for his sin" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: That man must carry his sin

contextId.information: Here Moses speaks about Yahweh causing their enemies to flee from the people of Israel as if they were fleeing from Yahweh himself. AT: "Make those who hate you run away from your ark and your people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Make those who hate you run from you

contextId.information: God speaks of the responsibility of leading and providing for the people as if it were a burden that Moses and the leaders would carry. AT: "You will not care for them alone" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You will not have to bear it alone

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) God speaks of vomiting as if the food would come out through their nostrils. AT: "until you are sick and vomit" or 2) they would eat so much meat that it would be as if it would come out of their nostrils. AT: "until it feels like it would have to come out of your nostrils" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: until it comes out of your nostrils

contextId.information: Having power from the Spirit is spoken of as if the Spirit rested on them. AT: "When they had power from the Spirit" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: When the Spirit rested on them

contextId.information: The Spirit giving them power is spoken of as if the Spirit rested on them. AT: "The Spirit also gave them power" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The Spirit also rested on them

contextId.information: The shape of the cloud is spoken of as if it were a pillar. AT: "a cloud shaped like a pillar" or "a tall cloud" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: a pillar of cloud

contextId.information: Yahweh's anger is spoken of as if it were a fire. AT: "Yahweh became very angry with them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh's anger burned against them

contextId.information: Being sent out of the camp and not being allowed to go back in is spoken of as if there were a door that was closed behind her. AT: "Miriam was sent outside the camp" or "Miriam was kept outside the camp" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Miriam was shut outside the camp

contextId.information: "Milk and honey certainly flow there." They spoke of the land being good for animals and plants as if the milk and honey from those animals and plants were flowing through the land. AT: "It is certainly excellent for raising livestock and growing crops" or "It is certainly very fertile land"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: It certainly flows with milk and honey

contextId.information: The men speak of the land, or the people of the land, being very dangerous as if the land ate up people. AT: "a very dangerous land" or "a land where the people will kill us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: a land that eats up its inhabitants

contextId.information: They spoke of the land being good for animals and plants as if the milk and honey from those animals and plants flowed through it. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:num:13:27|13:27]]. AT: "It is excellent for raising livestock and growing crops" or "It is very fertile land" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The land flows with milk and honey

contextId.information: Joshua and Caleb speak of destroying their enemies as if they were to eat them. AT: "We will destroy them as easily as we can eat food" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: We will consume them as easily as food

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) Moses speaks of God showing himself to his people as if God had allowed them to actually see his face. AT: "they have seen you"  or 2) Moses speaks of the intimate relationship between him and God as if Moses could see God's face when God spoke to him. This can be stated in active form. AT: "you speak directly to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]]and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: you are seen face to face

contextId.information: Killing them all at the same time is spoken of as killing them as one person. AT: "all at one time" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: as one man

contextId.information: "he will certainly not clear guilty people." Clearing away people's sin is a metaphor for refusing to punish them. God would not clear away the sin of guilty people. AT: "He will always punish the guilty" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He will by no means clear the guilty

contextId.information: "to produce from the herd or flock a smell that pleases Yahweh." The Lord's pleasure with the aroma represents his pleasure with the person who burns the offering. AT: "to please Yahweh by burning a sacrifice from the herd or the flock" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to produce a pleasing aroma for Yahweh from the herd or the flock

contextId.information: "It will produce a smell that pleases Yahweh." The Lord's pleasure with the aroma represents his pleasure with the person who burns the offering. AT: "You will please Yahweh by offering it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: It will produce a sweet aroma for Yahweh

contextId.information: "to produce a smell that pleases Yahweh." The Lord being pleased with the sincere worshiper who offers the sacrifice is spoken of as if God were pleased with the aroma of the sacrifice. AT: "to please Yahweh by offering it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to produce a sweet aroma for Yahweh

contextId.information: "to produce a smell that pleases Yahweh." Yahweh being pleased with the sincere worshiper who offers the sacrifice is spoken of as if Yahweh were pleased with the aroma of the sacrifice. AT: "to please Yahweh by offering it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to produce an aroma that is pleasing to Yahweh

contextId.information: "to produce a smell that pleases Yahweh." The Lord being pleased with the sincere worshiper who offers the sacrifice is spoken of as if God were pleased with the aroma of the sacrifice. AT: "to please Yahweh by offering it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to produce a sweet aroma for Yahweh

contextId.information: "to produce a smell that pleases Yahweh." The Lord being pleased with the sincere worshipers who offer the sacrifice is spoken of as if God were pleased with the aroma of the sacrifice. AT: "to please Yahweh by burning it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to produce a sweet aroma for Yahweh

contextId.information: "Look to" here is a metaphor for think about. The heart represents what a person wants, and the eyes represent what a person sees and wants.  AT  "so that you do not think about whatever you want" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: so that you do not look to your own heart and your own eyes

contextId.information: Being unfaithful to God by choosing to do whatever they want is spoken of as if they were women who were unfaithful to their husband by choosing to have sinful relationships with other men. It can be stated clearly that this was a shameful thing to do. AT: "be shamefully unfaithful to me" or "do those things instead of obeying me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: prostitute yourselves to them

contextId.information: Rebelling or criticizing someone in authority is spoken of as if they were standing up to fight. AT: "rebelled against Moses" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: rose up against Moses

contextId.information: Considering someone to be important is spoken of as lifting it up. AT: "consider yourselves more important than the rest" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: lift up yourselves above the rest

contextId.information: Wanting to have the priesthood is spoken of as if they were looking for it.  AT:  "you want to have the priesthood too" or "you want to be priests also" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you are seeking the priesthood also

contextId.information: They spoke of the land being good for animals and plants as if the milk and honey from those animals and plants were flowing through the land. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:num:14:06|14:08]]. AT: "that is excellent for raising livestock and growing crops" or "a very fertile land" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: a land flowing with milk and honey

contextId.information: They speak of promises that are not kept as if they are empty containers. AT: "with promises that you do not keep" or "by promising to do things that you do not do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: with empty promises

contextId.information: Being destroyed is spoken of as if they would be eaten. AT: "you will be destroyed"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you will be consumed

contextId.information: Being destroyed because of their sins is spoken of as if the sins would destroy them. AT: "you will be destroyed because of all their sins"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you will be consumed by all their sins

contextId.information: Moses speaks of the earth as if it were alive, and the hole that the people fell into as if it were the earth's mouth. AT: "The earth opened up like a large mouth, and they fell into it and were buried in it" or "There was a giant hole in the ground, and they fell into it and were buried in it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The earth opened its mouth and swallowed them

contextId.information: The people speak of the earth as if it were alive. AT: "The earth might open up and we too will fall into it" or "If the earth opens up again, we too will fall into it and be buried" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The earth may swallow us up also

contextId.information: God speaks of destroying them as if he would eat them. AT: "so that I may destroy them" or "and I will destroy them"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: so that I may consume them

contextId.information: Yahweh appointing the Levites to help Aaron is spoken of as if they were a gift that Yahweh were giving to Aaron. AT: "They are like a gift to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: They are a gift to you

contextId.information: Being acceptable to God is spoken of as if they were clean. AT: "Everyone in your family who is acceptable to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Everyone who is clean in your family

contextId.information: The Lord's pleasure with the aroma represents his pleasure with the person who burns the offering. AT: "and Yahweh will be pleased with you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: an aroma pleasing to Yahweh

contextId.information: God speaks of the land that the other people will possess as if they will inherit it. AT: "You will not possess any of the people's land" or "You will not receive any of the land that the Israelites will possess" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You will have no inheritance in the people's land

contextId.information: God speaks of the great honor that Aaron and his descendants will have by serving him as priests as if God were something that they will inherit. AT: "Instead, I am what you will have" or "Instead, I will allow you to serve me and I will provide for you through that service" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I am your share and inheritance

contextId.information: God speaks of what Aaron and his descendants will receive as if they will inherit it. AT: "as their portion of what I give to all Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: as their inheritance

contextId.information: God speaks of the land that the other people of Israel will possess as if they will inherit it. The Levites would not receive any of the land. AT: "they must not have any of the land that the other people of Israel receive"   (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Among the people of Israel they must have no inheritance

contextId.information: God speaks of what Aaron and his descendants will receive as if they will inherit it. AT: "as your portion of what I give to all Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: for your inheritance

contextId.information: Being unacceptable to God or unfit to do any sacred work is spoken of as not being clean. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: he will remain unclean

contextId.information: Being acceptable to God and fit to do sacred work is spoken of as being clean. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Someone who is clean

contextId.information: Being acceptable to God is spoken of as being clean. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: in a clean place

contextId.information: Here the phrase "be cut off" means to be disowned and sent away. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:num:09:13|9:13]]. AT: "That person must be sent away" or "you must send that person away" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: That person must be cut off

contextId.information: Balaam's report is spoken of as if it were something that he would carry to the messengers. AT: "I will tell you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will bring you

contextId.information: The message is spoken of as if it is something that God put into his mouth. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:num:22:38|22:38]]. AT: "told him what to say" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: put a message in his mouth

contextId.information: This verse is a long metaphor that speaks of Israel defeating her enemies as if Israel was a lion devouring its prey. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the people rise like a lioness ... he has killed

contextId.information: Balaam speaks of the Israelites as if they are wild animals that eat their enemies. This means they will destroy their enemies. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He will eat up the nations

contextId.information: This is a metaphor that means that they live in a secure place. AT: "your location is as secure as a nest high in the rocks" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: your nest is in the rocks

contextId.information: Here Yahweh speaks about the land that his is giving the Israel as if he has already given it to them. He speaks this way to emphasize that his committed to give it to them. AT: "that I will give to the people of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: that I have given to the people of Israel

contextId.information: Here Moses speaks of a person promising to do something as if his promise were a physical object that he ties to himself. AT: "committing to fulfill a promise" or "promising to do something" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to bind himself with a promise

contextId.information: The phrase "his word" refers to a man's oaths and vows. Here Moses speaks of not fulfilling these as if they were physical objects that the man could break. AT: "he must fulfill his promises" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: he must not break his word

contextId.information: Here Moses speaks of a woman promising to do something as if her promise were a physical object that she ties to herself. AT: "commits herself to fulfilling a promise" or "promises to do something" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: binds herself with a promise

contextId.information: Here Moses speaks of how a woman has committed herself to fulfilling a promise as if her promise were a physical object that she had bound to her body. AT: "which she has committed herself to fulfill" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: by which she has bound herself

contextId.information: Here the woman committing herself to fulfilling her vows is spoken of as if her vows were a garment that she placed on herself. AT: "that she committed herself to" or "that she made" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: she took on herself

contextId.information: Here Moses speaks of how a woman has committed herself to fulfilling a promise as if her promise were a physical object that she had bound to her body. AT: "her solemn promises which she has committed herself to fulfill" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: her solemn promises with which she has bound herself

contextId.information: Here Moses speaks about Yahweh forgiving the woman for not fulfilling her vow as if he were releasing her from something that bound her. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. AT: "Yahweh will forgive her" or "Yahweh will forgive her for not fulfilling her vow" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh will release her

contextId.information: Here Moses speaks of how a woman has committed herself to fulfilling a promise as if her promise were a physical object that she had bound to her body. AT: "which she has committed herself to fulfill" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: by which she has bound herself

contextId.information: Here Moses speaks about Yahweh forgiving the woman for not fulfilling her vow as if he were releasing her from something that bound her. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. AT: "Yahweh will forgive her" or "Yahweh will forgive her for not fulfilling her vow" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh will release her

contextId.information: Moses describes a woman's promises as if they were something that she is physically bound by. AT: "obligations" or "promises" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: binding promises

contextId.information: Yahweh becoming angry is spoken of as if his anger was a fire that begins to burn. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Yahweh became very angry with Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh's anger was kindled against Israel

contextId.information: The people of Reuben and Gad acting like their ancestors did is spoken of as if they were standing in the place where their ancestors did. AT: "you have begun to act just like your ancestors" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you have risen up in your fathers' place

contextId.information: The land that the people were to receive as a permanent possession is spoken of as if it were an inheritance that they were to obtain. AT: "has taken possession of his portion of the land" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: has obtained his inheritance

contextId.information: The land that the people were to receive as a permanent possession is spoken of as if it were an inheritance that they were to obtain. AT: "the portion of land that we will possess" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: our possessed inheritance

contextId.information: Yahweh proving that he is more powerful than all of the false gods that the Egyptians worshiped is spoken of as if Yahweh punished those false gods. AT: "he also proved that he is greater than their gods" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: he also inflicted punishment on their gods

contextId.information: The Israelites claiming the land as their permanent possession is spoken of as if they were inheriting the land. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: inherit the land

contextId.information: Someone intentionally seeking a way to harm another person is spoken of as if someone were hiding in order to ambush that other person. AT: "without intentionally having tried to harm the victim" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: without lying in wait

contextId.information: Making the land unacceptable to Yahweh is spoken of as if it were physically polluting the land. AT: "Do not make the land where you live unacceptable to me in this way, because blood from murder makes the land unacceptable to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Do not pollute in this way the land where you live, because blood from murder pollutes the land

contextId.information: The land that each clan possesses is spoken of as if it were an inheritance that they received. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: may own an inheritance

contextId.information: Transferring ownership from one tribe to another is spoken of as if the property passed from one person's hands to another person's hands. AT: "No one may transfer the ownership of any share of land from one tribe to another" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: No share may change hands from one tribe to another
